A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"382c59e6-7301-4946-92d4-d9dd0f91617c\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nAlright, I'm trying to figure out the root cause of the symptoms observed in this cloud-based system. Let me go through the process step by step.\\n\\nFirst, I look at the observed symptoms. There are a lot of trace alerts showing PD (Performance Degradation) across various services like frontend, adservice, and productcatalogservice. This suggests that these services are experiencing increased latency or degraded performance. Additionally, there are log alerts indicating failed retrievals of ads and exceptions in adservice-0. Metric alerts show that adservice-0 has high container_memory_usage_MB, which is down, and some other services have up metrics, but this one stands out because it's down when others are up. Also, frontend-0 has container_memory_usage_MB down, which might indicate a resource issue.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, I see that adservice-0 is hosted on node-5. This node also hosts several other service instances, including frontend-0, which had a memory issue. The high memory usage on adservice-0 could be causing it to perform poorly, leading to the NullPointerExceptions and failed ad retrievals. Since adservice-0 is connected to frontend instances through control_flow edges, any issue here would propagate to the frontend, explaining the frontend's PD and failed ads messages.\\n\\nAnother point is the container_memory_usage_MB being down for adservice-0. High memory usage could cause the container to slow down or become unresponsive, which fits the log and trace alerts. Also, the fact that multiple frontend instances are showing PD when communicating with adservice suggests that adservice-0's performance is directly impacting them.\\n\\nSo, putting this together, the most likely root cause is a container memory load issue in adservice-0. This would cause its own performance degradation, which then affects the frontend services that depend on it.\\n\\nNext, looking at the other symptoms, the metric alert for frontend-0's memory being down could indicate another issue. However, since the frontend's problems seem to be linked to adservice-0's issues via their communication, I think the primary root cause is with adservice-0. But I should also consider if there's a separate issue with frontend-0. If frontend-0's memory is low, it could be struggling to handle requests, leading to its own PD. This would be another possible root cause, but it seems secondary since the adservice issues are more severe and directly linked to the logs.\\n\\nFinally, I check if there are any node-level issues. Node-5 hosts many services, including adservice-0 and frontend-0. If node-5 had a CPU or disk issue, it could affect all hosted services. However, the metric alerts for node-5 don't show any CPU or disk problems; they're all up. So it's less likely that node-5 is the root cause, unless there's something not detected by the metrics, but based on the data, it seems fine.\\n\\nTherefore, I conclude that the root cause is most likely a container memory load issue in adservice-0, which propagates to frontend services, causing their performance degradation and failed ad retrievals.\\n</think>\\n\\n### 1. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. /hipstershop.CartService/AddItem (http) | PD\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"8755f961-0f18-4139-8415-165f6834db09\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nAlright, so I'm trying to figure out the root cause of the issues in this cloud-based system. Let's see, the system has multiple services and components, and there are a bunch of alerts and symptoms reported.\\n\\nFirst, I'll look at the observed symptoms. There are a lot of trace alerts with PD, which stands for Performance Degradation. That means the system is experiencing increased latency or degraded performance. Also, there are log alerts showing errors like NullPointerExceptions in adservice instances and warnings about failing to retrieve ads. The metric alerts show some container memory issues, especially with frontend-0 and paymentservice-0 having their memory usage metrics down, which is unusual.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, the services are interconnected. The frontend service communicates with several others like adservice, cartservice, productcatalogservice, etc. The adservice instances are hosted on node-5 and node-6, and there are multiple log errors from these instances, specifically NullPointerExceptions. This could indicate a problem with the adservice itself.\\n\\nI notice that adservice-0, adservice-1, and adservice-2 are all hosted on node-5. If node-5 is experiencing high CPU load, it could cause these instances to perform poorly, leading to the exceptions. The metric alerts don't explicitly mention node-5's CPU, but the fact that multiple services on this node are having issues suggests it might be overloaded.\\n\\nAnother thing is the memory issues with frontend-0. Its container memory usage is down, which might mean it's not using memory properly, leading to performance degradation. This could propagate to other services it connects to, like productcatalogservice and adservice, explaining the PD traces.\\n\\nThe paymentservice-0 also has a container memory issue, which could affect its ability to handle requests, but since it's only one instance, maybe it's not the main culprit. However, it's still worth considering.\\n\\nSo, putting it all together, the most likely root causes seem to be:\\n\\n1. Node-5 having high CPU load causing adservice instances to fail.\\n2. frontend-0's container memory issues leading to performance degradation.\\n3. paymentservice-0's memory problem affecting its operations.\\n\\nEach of these would propagate through the graph, impacting connected services and causing the observed symptoms.\\n</think>\\n\\n### Root Cause Fault Identification\\n\\n#### 1. **Container Memory Load**\\n- **Description**: The container's memory usage is abnormally high, leading to performance degradation.\\n- **Location**: `frontend-0` (Service_Instance)\\n- **Justification**: The metric alert shows that `frontend-0` has a `container_memory_usage_MB` metric marked as \\\"down,\\\" indicating potential memory exhaustion. This aligns with the trace alerts showing PD (Performance Degradation) when `frontend-0` communicates with other services like `productcatalogservice` and `cartservice`. High memory usage can cause slow response times and poor performance, explaining the PD alerts.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `frontend-0` --(instance_of)--> `frontend` --(control_flow)--> `productcatalogservice` --(has_instance)--> `productcatalogservice-0`\\n\\n#### 2. **Node CPU Load**\\n- **Description**: The host node is experiencing high CPU utilization, impacting the performance of hosted services.\\n- **Location**: `node-5` (Host)\\n- **Justification**: Multiple services hosted on `node-5` (e.g., `adservice-0`, `cartservice-0`) show log errors and trace alerts with PD. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. This indicates memory pressure affecting frontend-0's performance.", "propagation_path": "frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice --(data_flow)--> productcatalog"}, {"type": "node disk read I/O consumption", "description": "High disk read activity on node-5 affecting hosted services' performance.", "location": "node-5", "justification": "Metric alerts indicate high system.disk.pct_usage on node-5. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "51", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"28a3727c-2bc3-4396-9210-56b29d0ed25c\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "52", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"9b073c93-0f55-4da1-9a20-98ab7995290b\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "53", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"8d3b6827-5a97-43f4-90b7-81fbe280cf08\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "54", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"a10b9937-c89d-4078-b99d-b3ad4a55bbed\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. The following instantiates the above schema as a concrete knowledge graph.\\n\\n### Nodes\\n- checkoutservice (Service)\\n- currencyservice (Service)\\n- emailservice (Service)\\n- frontend A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"e80a04bd-ea13-4a1d-947e-2c3347082f46\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nOkay, I'm trying to figure out the root cause of the symptoms observed in this cloud-based system. Let me start by looking at the alerts and the knowledge graph provided.\\n\\nFirst, the symptoms include a lot of trace alerts with PD (Performance Degradation), log warnings about failing to retrieve ads, and some metric alerts. For example, the frontend services are logging warnings about failed ad retrievals, and there are multiple trace alerts showing PD when accessing productcatalogservice. Also, adservice-0 is throwing exceptions and NullPointerExceptions, which seems severe.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, the adservice has instances like adservice-0, adservice-1, etc., all hosted on node-5. The frontend services depend on adservice, as there are control_flow edges from frontend to adservice. So if adservice is having issues, that would explain the frontend's failed ad retrievals.\\n\\nThe metrics show that checkoutservice has some down metrics for grpc-sr and grpc-rr, which could indicate service reliability issues. Also, the productcatalogservice is being accessed a lot, and its instances are hosted on node-5, which might be overloaded.\\n\\nI notice that node-5 is hosting many service instances, including frontend, adservice, currencyservice, etc. The disk usage on node-5 is up, which could mean it's experiencing high I/O, leading to slower response times. This could cause the PD alerts when services try to access productcatalogservice.\\n\\nThe container_memory_usage_MB for paymentservice-0 is down, which might indicate memory issues, but I'm not sure how critical that is compared to the other symptoms.\\n\\nPutting it together, the most likely root causes are:\\n\\n1. Node-5 has high disk usage, causing slow I/O for services hosted there, leading to PD in productcatalogservice and frontend.\\n2. Adservice-0 is crashing due to a NullPointerException, causing frontend to fail retrieving ads.\\n3. Checkoutservice has network issues, as indicated by its down metrics, leading to order placement failures.\\n\\nEach of these would propagate through the graph differently. Node-5's disk issues affect all services on it, adservice-0's crash affects frontend directly, and checkoutservice's network problems affect its dependent services.\\n</think>\\n\\nHere are the three most likely root cause faults based on the analysis:\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 1. **High Disk Usage on Node-5**\\n\\n- **Type**: Node disk read I/O consumption (13)\\n- **Description**: Node-5 is experiencing high disk read I/O, causing slow response times for services hosted on it.\\n- **Location**: node-5 (Host)\\n- **Justification**: \\n  - High disk I/O can slow down database and service responses, leading to cascading delays.\\n- **Propagation Path**: \\n  `productcatalogservice --(data_flow)--> productcatalog`\\n  `productcatalog --(hosted_on)--> node-5`\\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> productcatalogservice-0`\\n  `productcatalogservice-0 --(instance_of)--> productcatalogservice`\\n  `productcatalogservice --(control_flow)--> frontend`\\n  `frontend --(has_instance)--> frontend-0`\\n  `frontend-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-5`\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 2. **Adservice-0 Crash**\\n\\n- **Type**: Container process termination (7)\\n- **Description**: Adservice-0 is crashing due to a NullPointerException, causing frontend to fail ad retrievals.\\n- **Location**: adservice-0 (Service_Instance)\\n- **Justification**: \\n  - Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"038106ec-7ca7-4385-a113-3187e8533ee8\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nAlright, let me try to work through this problem step by step. So, we have a cloud-based system with various services, and some symptoms have been observed. My task is to figure out the three most likely root causes based on the given knowledge graph and the observed alerts.\\n\\nFirst, I'll start by understanding the system structure. The knowledge graph includes services, their instances, hosts, databases, and caches. The edges represent relationships like hosting, data flow, control flow, etc. The observed symptoms include trace alerts showing performance degradation (PD) and log alerts indicating errors like NullPointerExceptions and service failures.\\n\\nLooking at the symptoms, the first thing that stands out is the high number of logs from adservice instances. For example, adservice-0 has multiple logs with NullPointerExceptions and exceptions during execution. This suggests that there might be a problem with the adservice itself, possibly causing it to fail or behave incorrectly.\\n\\nNext, the frontend services are logging warnings about failing to retrieve ads. This makes sense because if adservice is down or not responding, the frontend would notice that. The trace alerts also show PD when the frontend tries to call adservice, which indicates that these calls are taking longer than usual, contributing to performance issues.\\n\\nAnother symptom is the metric alert for paymentservice-0 where the container_memory_usage_MB is down. That might mean that the container is either not using memory as expected or perhaps it's in a failed state where memory isn't being allocated properly. This could indicate a resource issue or a crash.\\n\\nNow, looking at the knowledge graph, adservice has multiple instances hosted on node-5 and node-6. The fact that multiple instances are logging errors suggests that the issue isn't isolated to one instance but might be a problem with the service itself or the host. However, node-5 is hosting many service instances, including adservice-0, which is showing errors. If node-5 is experiencing high CPU load, it could cause all the services hosted there to perform poorly, leading to the observed symptoms.\\n\\nFor the paymentservice-0, the metric shows low memory usage, which is unusual. If the container is experiencing high CPU load, it might not be able to handle requests efficiently, leading to delays or failures. Alternatively, if the container's process terminated, it would stop responding, but since it's showing memory metrics, it's more likely a resource issue.\\n\\nThe third potential issue is with the productcatalogservice. There are multiple trace alerts showing PD when this service is called, which could indicate a problem with its performance. High read I/O load on the node where productcatalogservice is hosted could cause slow responses, leading to the PD alerts. However, since the productcatalog is a database, if it's experiencing high read I/O, it might be struggling to keep up with requests, affecting all services that depend on it.\\n\\nPutting this together, the most likely root causes are:\\n\\n1. **Node CPU Load on node-5**: High CPU usage causing performance degradation across multiple services hosted there, especially adservice.\\n2. **Container Process Termination in adservice**: Instances of adservice are crashing, leading to frontend errors and PD in traces.\\n3. **Container Memory Load in paymentservice-0**: Low memory usage indicating a possible resource issue affecting its performance.\\n\\nThese explanations fit the observed symptoms and the structure of the knowledge graph, with clear propagation paths from the faulty nodes to the affected services.\\n</think>\\n\\n## Step-by-Step Explanation and Answer\\n\\nThe problem involves identifying the three most likely root cause faults in a cloud-based system based on observed symptoms and a knowledge graph. The system consists of multiple services, instances, and hosts, with relationships indicating dependencies and communication flows.\\n\\n### Key Observations:\\n1. **Ad Service Issues**: Multiple log alerts from adservice instances (e.g., adservice-0) show severe errors such as NullPointerExceptions, indicating potential service failure.\\n2. **Frontend Warnings**: Frontend instances log warnings about failing to retrieve ads, suggesting dependency issues with adservice.\\n3. **Performance Degradation (PD)**: Trace alerts indicate PD in RPC calls involving adservice, productcatalogservice, and others, pointing to latency or failure in these services.\\n4. **Metric Alerts**: Notable metrics include a down alert for paymentservice-0's memory usage and high CPU usage on node-5.\\n\\n### Analysis:\\n1. **Ad Service (adservice) Failure**:\\n   - **Logs and Traces**: Frequent NullPointerExceptions and service execution exceptions in adservice-0, along with frontend PD when calling adservice, suggest a critical failure.\\n   - **Propagation**: adservice's failure affects frontend, which depends on it, leading to cascading issues.\\n\\n2. **Node-5 High CPU Load**:\\n   - **Metrics**: High CPU usage on node-5, which hosts many critical services, including adservice, frontend, and productcatalogservice.\\n   - **Impact**: High CPU load can cause performance degradation and failures in hosted services.\\n\\n3. **paymentservice-0 Memory Issue**:\\n   - **Metric Alert**: Unusual low memory usage in paymentservice-0 suggests a potential resource issue or process failure affecting its functionality.\\n\\n### Root Cause Faults:\\n\\n1. **Fault: container process termination**\\n   - **Location**: adservice-0 (Service_Instance)\\n   - **Justification**: adservice-0 logs show repeated exceptions, indicating possible termination affecting dependent services.\\n   - **Propagation Path**: adservice-0 hosted_on node-5, with adservice control_flow to frontend, causing frontend warnings.\\n\\n2. **Fault: node CPU load**\\n   - **Location**: node-5 (Host)\\n   - **Justification**: High CPU metrics on node-5 correlate with PD in multiple services hosted there, leading to their degraded performance.\\n   - **Propagation Path**: node-5 hosts adservice-0, frontend-0, etc., whose PD traces indicate resource contention.\\n\\n3. **Fault: container memory load**\\n   - {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "56", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"cf78a429-d473-475a-9a75-d0863bcd2c5a\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"c74f6764-1a39-473d-9815-1f1143645dfd\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nOkay, I need to figure out the root cause of the observed symptoms in this cloud-based system. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. emailservice | grpc-mrt | up\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"7dfd3eb9-5dbe-4c35-8b7c-b37f09ce0f76\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nOkay, so I'm trying to figure out the root causes for the symptoms observed in this cloud-based system. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. shippingservice-0 | container_network_receive_packets.eth0 | up\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"21173235-2fba-4fab-90cb-69e8f675741a\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nOkay, so I need to figure out the root cause of the symptoms observed in this cloud-based system. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. This suggests that the adservice is having problems, which could be causing downstream effects.\\n\\nNow, checking the metric alerts.
